title: Klaus Sammer
text:
Klaus Sammer (born 5 December 1942) is a German former <a href="Association%20football">footballer</a> and coach. He spent the early part of his career with Stahl Gröditz and <a href="SC%20Einheit%20Dresden">Einheit Dresden</a>, before joining <a href="Dynamo%20Dresden">Dynamo Dresden</a>, the club where he would spend the majority of his career, in 1965. In eleven seasons as a Dynamo player he won two <a href="DDR-Oberliga">East German titles</a> and one <a href="FDGB%20Pokal">cup</a>, and played 17 times for the <a href="East%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">East German national team</a>. After retiring in 1975 he took up coaching, and managed Dynamo Dresden from 1983 to 1986, winning two cups in a period dominated by the state-favoured <a href="BFC%20Dynamo">BFC Dynamo</a>. His tenure ended after a disastrous defeat against <a href="Bayer%20Uerdingen">Bayer Uerdingen</a> in the <a href="UEFA%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">Cup Winners' Cup</a> – Dynamo were 2–0 up after the first leg, and 3–1 up at half-time in the second, but proceeded to be knocked out with a 7–3 defeat. He returned to the manager's job in 1992, with the club now in the <a href="Bundesliga">Bundesliga</a> after <a href="German%20reunification">reunification</a>, but this spell only lasted one year. He has since worked in various roles for the <a href="German%20Football%20Association">German Football Association</a>.
Klaus Sammer is the father of <a href="Matthias%20Sammer">Matthias Sammer</a>, who began his career under him at Dynamo Dresden, and went on to play for both <a href="East%20Germany%20national%20football%20team">East Germany</a> and the united <a href="Germany%20national%20football%20team">Germany</a>, and was <a href="Ballon%20d%27Or">European Player of the Year</a> in 1996.
